intro: Quercus dalechampii var. grandifolia, commonly known as the California black oak, is a deciduous tree native to the western United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its dark, fissured bark and lobed, alternate leaves. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for wildlife. It typically grows in mixed coniferous and oak woodlands, preferring well-drained soils. The species is notable for its adaptability to various environmental conditions and its ecological significance in its native range.
